description: Circa 1400, Middle French, from Latin indigentem, from indigēre (“to need”), from indu (“in, within”) + egēre (“be in need, want”).

adjectives.description: indigent (comparative more indigent, superlative most indigent)

entries.meaning: (archaic) Utterly lacking or in need of something specified.
examples: Again some Bodies dissolve both in Fire and Water, as Gums; &c. And these are such, as have both Plenty of Spirit; and their tangible Parts indigent of Moisture: the former promotes the Dilatation of the Spirits by the Fire and the latter stimulates the Parts to receive the Liquor.

entries.meaning: A person in need, or in poverty.
